results.title: Independent Nigeria
results.creator_credit: George Sturt, Beric Knight-Simpson, Federal Film Unit and Nigeria. Federal Information Unit
results.brief_description: Nigeria on the eve of independence. Gives a general picture of the country, showing its progress in economic, political and social spheres. Recent developments in agriculture and industry; medical education and social services; housing and transport, are illustrated. Describes the different races, religions and customs of the people of Nigeria, and includes colourful scenes of traditional pageantry.

results.title: Independence Day USA
results.creator_credit: John G. Fuller and United States Information Agency
results.brief_description: Describes the various ways in which individual Americans celebrate their Independence Day, July 4th. They honour the heroes responsible for the Declaration of Independence and the national ideals of human rights embodied in it.

results.title: Incredible Floridas
results.creator_credit: Peter Weir, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description: Incredible Floridas is composer Richard Meale’s homage to the French poet, Arthur Rimbaud. Scored for woodwind, percussion and string instruments, it was written for the “Fires of London” and their conductor, Peter Maxwell Davies, and premiered in London in 1971 to a enthusiastic reception. Richard Meale is a leader in contemporary music in Australia. Also available on DVD [319174].
results.creator_credit_for_label: Peter Weir, Malcolm Otton and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: [The Incredible bread machine]
results.creator_credit: Theo Kamecke, John W. Doswell and World Research
results.brief_description: Based on a book of the same title by R. W. Grant, first published in 1966, and updated and extensively revised by Susan Love Brown and the student staff of Campus Studies Institute, World Research, under the supervision of Patty Newman in 1974. This docudrama film contains re-enactments based on true facts of various events that took place during the 1960’s and 1970’s relating to government department abuse of individual freedom and choice. For example, an Amish farmer who could not pay his taxes and subsequently lost his farm (which eventually turned into a parking lot), and a police agent drug bust on the wrong house (with no compensation to the couple who lived there). It focuses on government regulation and intervention, lobbyists and monopolies versus people’s freedom of choice and the right to food, shelter and equality.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Theo Kamecke, John W. Doswell and World Research

results.title: The Incredible art of animation
results.brief_description: An introduction to the basic techniques of animation, the film demonstrates the recording of sound, speech, music and the animation of sketches. Designed to stimulate interest in this art at the amateur film making level.

results.title: The Incomplete
results.creator_credit: Zdenka Doycheva and State Distribution Centre
results.brief_description: A little boy is drawing happily when, suddenly, the telephone rings. While the artist is away a feud develops between the two animated figures. Just as one is about to pronounce himself victorious, the boy returns and quickly provides a happy ending for all. No commentary - music and sound effects only.

results.title: Incendio (D)
results.creator_credit: Craig Johnson, Eliot Tarlin and National Fire Protection Association (U.S.)
results.brief_description: This film is based on information gathered for a joint investigation of the Joelma Building fire in Sao Paulo, Brazil in 1974 by the National Fire Protection Association and the National Bureau of Standards (US Dept of Commerce). It is a sobering and haunting account of a real-life “towering inferno” - two hours of fire, 179 dead. It contains graphic and disturbing images of people leaping to their death. However, it also shows firefighting and rescue efforts and uses animation to show how fires spread in high rise buildings. Electronic score by Robert Ceely.
